Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Manihiki and Rakahanga: Persistence on the Margins of Oceania

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Human populations colonized and transformed many of the Earth's most marginal environments including deserts, mountains, and remote islands. In doing so they encountered unique environmental challenges and altered their behavior and the environment itself to match their cultural ideals and needs. Manihiki and Rakahanga, two remote and resource-poor atolls in the South Pacific Ocean, provide a unique small-scale setting to investigate the ways that human populations transformed and managed marginal environments to create long-term sustainability. The research team will use archaeological methods to investigate the processes of social and environmental transformation that sustained the people of Manihiki and Rakahanga for nearly 1,000 years, while investigating the role that the northern Cook Islands played in the colonization of East Polynesia. By training local assistants in archaeological methods, principles of site preservation, and highly applicable technical skills, this project will also provide local education opportunities, while encouraging the protection of local cultural resources. The completion of this research will result in a time line for human/environmental interaction on the atolls that stretches from island formation, during late-Holocene sea level fall, through to the historic period (roughly 1849 AD). The perspectives of historical ecology and resilience theory will be used to contextualize and explain how the long-term habitation of these atolls was accomplished. Combined, these efforts will facilitate a deep-time understanding of the ways that humans construct landscapes and develop conservation/ management practices that can sustain populations in even the most marginal environments. The results of this research will be shared through presentations and publications aimed at academic audiences, as well as local Cook Islands populations to inform and inspire conversations about local and global challenges regarding landscape management.

This research draws from multiple socioecological perspectives. Historical ecology, is a research perspective that accepts the challenges of environmental conditions, while recognizing that humans can manipulate landscapes to create long-term trajectories of continuity and change. Resilience theory offers a complimentary viewpoint that contextualizes the processes that shape landscapes in terms of key social and ecological variables. Combined these frameworks will be used to address the following question: Through what processes and over what time scales have humans transformed and managed marginal or emerging environments to create resilient cultural landscapes? The research team will use archaeological field methods, including the excavation of habitation and resource procurement areas on Manihiki and Rakahanga to identify changing settlement patterns and physical landform alterations (i.e., the construction of horticultural fields). Laboratory analysis of the excavated materials will include zooarchaeological analysis of faunal remains to trace changes in local ecologies and resource use, foraminifera analysis to identify markers of atoll formation, and an extensive AMS radiocarbon dating program to define time spans for events in the landscape trajectories of the atolls. Combined these methods will answer this research question by revealing the long-term patterns of settlement, resource use, and landscape alteration that shaped long-term sustainability on these marginal atolls.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research uses the perspective of historical ecology to investigate human-environmental interaction on the atolls of Manihiki and Rakahanga (M&R) in the Northern Cook Islands. By applying historical ecology to the question of Indigenous sustainable development, this study generates a novel deep-time understanding of how people influence sustainability through the creation of novel sociopolitical and socioecological institutions. In doing so it adds to the global interdisciplinary effort to understand how sustainable food systems have been, and can be, realized.

M&R are located in a geographically remote area of East Polynesia. Coral atolls are one of the world?s most understudied landforms, and East Polynesian atolls are rarely the subject of archaeological and zooarchaeological research. Therefore, this work greatly furthers our knowledge of the cultures and ecologies that developed on East Polynesian atolls. The islets that form M&R emerged during late Holocene sea-level fall. Oral traditions and Ethnographic reports describe a novel dual-chiefdom political system and suggest that the ecological resources of M&R were managed through a regionally unique cyclical mass-migration system, called the Tumutu. In this system the entire population voyaged the 45km between the atolls leaving one island populated and the other uninhabited. Ethnohistoric accounts suggest that the entire population lived in a single village on Rakahanga called Te Kainga, literally "the home."  When resources ran low on Rakahanga the people periodically voyaged to Manihiki. Using archaeological, ethnographic, ethnohistoric, and zooarchaeological methods and data, we investigated the dynamics of human arrival on M&R as well as the ways in which habitation and subsistence patterns changed over time to investigate the creation of these cultural institutions. 

The Co-PI Justin Cramb completed over 8-months of archaeological and ethnographic fieldwork on Manihiki and Rakahanga where he excavated four archaeological sites including two villages. During this time field assistants and volunteers were trained in archaeological field methods. Cramb also gave archaeological site tours and educational talks in schools on Manihiki and Rakahanga. He followed this fieldwork with the analysis of ethnographic interviews, survey data, artifacts, faunal remains, sediments, and stratigraphic data. He ran a suite radiocarbon dates which indicate that the first habitation of M&R was on the islet of Te Kainga between 1200 and 1400 AD. Shortly following this initial arrival villages are established on Manihiki. Following European contact in 1606 AD, the villages on Manihiki become less densely occupied and the village on Te Kainga is expanded marking population aggregation. This likely coincides with the development of the dual-chiefdom and the Tum?tu migrations. By missionization in 1849 AD, Manihiki is only used in times of need. Over the centuries between first occupation and missionization Rakahanga was heavily transformed by a population who dug extensive networks of puraka swamp taro (Cyrtosperma Spp.) pond fields on the largest islet. While not as extensive, each village on Manihiki contained a taro pit. The ubiquity of taro pits suggests that puraka was a key dietary staple that was carefully managed. Stone-walled fish traps were built on each atoll. The diet of the islanders through all pre-missionization time periods relied heavily on inshore and reef fishes with larger pelagic species caught infrequently. Domestic dogs (Canis familiaris) were introduced to the atolls at or shortly following human arrival. The dogs were mostly confined to Rakahanga and were later extirpated. The pattern of dog introduction and loss on M&R is reflected in similar patterns on small islands across the Pacific.  

This research suggests that the settlers of M&R had a long and complex history of social and ecological transformation as their population grew, developed, dispersed, and reconsolidated. They transformed the landscape by digging horticultural pits, constructing fish traps, and introducing domesticates. The implementation of the dual-chiefdom may have been a means of coping with the reconsolidation of semi-autonomous groups into the village on Te Kainga. The Tumutu likely developed as a way for lineages to periodically revisit and tend to their land on Manihiki following consolidation. The long-term experimentation with settlement patterns and subsistence practices resulted in the development of a sustainable socioecological system where an entire island was left to regenerate ensuring food availability in time of need while providing the social mechanisms needed to allow a large population to dwell on a small and remote island.

Combined, the efforts of this research make a significant contribution to Pacific Island archaeology and global sustainability science. Cramb has presented the findings of this research through public talks in the US, the Cook Islands, and New Zealand, where many Cook Islanders reside. This was done to disseminate findings to local populations and to engage with those populations to learn how this archaeological research articulates with traditional narratives and traditional ecological knowledge, as well as how it might fill gaps in long-forgotten knowledge.
